rewrite.title: Building an Online Vidalia Onion Business
rewrite.body:
In 2014, the domain VidaliaOnions.com became available after its original owner let it expire. Recognizing the brand potential tied to his Georgia roots, the entrepreneur acquired it at auction for roughly $2,200. Over the following months, the domain inspired a direct-to-consumer business model modeled after companies like Harry & David, but focused on delivering fresh Vidalia sweet onions.

Launching in February 2015 without external funding, the founder partnered with Aries Haygood, a farmer with 25 years of experience and an award-winning Vidalia crop. While the farm handled production and packing, the entrepreneur concentrated on marketing, customer service, and logistics. This division of labor allowed the business to scale efficiently, attracting customers nationwide and becoming a preferred mail-order source as other Vidalia sellers exited the market.

Marketing efforts extended beyond the website, including local sponsorships and a strategic billboard on I-95 near Savannah, Georgia. Despite early setbacks, such as a costly $10,000 mistake on shipping materials, the venture persevered, driven by strong customer loyalty and a niche product with consistent demand. The story exemplifies how domain-driven branding combined with persistent, hands-on entrepreneurship can carve out a successful online agricultural business without traditional venture capital.
